thread.title: Why the Brexit result proved the best result for Britain one year on

author: Mike Kelly
title: Why the Brexit result proved the best result for Britain one year on
text:

When it became apparent, in the early hours of June 24, that the county was going to vote ‘Leave’ in the European Union referendum I thought, using less colourful language now than I did then, we’ve mucked up here. 
How on earth could the North East, which has benefited so much from EU grants that are based on want and need rather than political affiliation, had opted to cut off this vital supply of funds? 
What about Nissan, I cried, like many other people, displaying sudden concern for a car factory like its theoretical post-Brexit demise would mean the earth beneath our feet would collapse. 
Yet today, when contemplating the first anniversary of what Nigel Farage described as ‘Independence Day’, I have to admit I now think it was the best result for Britain, all things considered. Read More Brexit one year on - the 12 key dates in a momentous year in British politics 
You think I’m wrong? Well imagine what would have happened if the country had voted ‘Remain’. 
David Cameron would still be Prime Minister and worse still George Osborne would still be Chancellor. That would have meant at the very least another three years of austerity. 
And in 2020, when the next general election was actually due, Jeremy Corbyn will be 71. Would he have still been Labour leader or would he have quit by then to work in his allotment, sick of the never-ending in-fighting of his party? Labour Leader Jeremy Corbyn (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
I’m sure, if the country had voted Remain, the Parliamentary Labour Party would have done its utmost to replace him with a candidate they believed suitably attractive to Middle England and in their mind ‘electable’. 
Instead the country - and Labour’s heartland - unexpectedly voted Brexit. Just as unexpectedly as many of them voted for Corbyn and Labour too at the general election. The contest was so close the Tories are now talking about ending austerity in order to be able to govern. 
Perversely, Labour MPs blamed Corbyn for Brexit as they believed everyone hated him as much as they did. 
So when Theresa May called the snap election, it seemed in many people’s mind he would go after a widely predicted heavy defeat for Labour. 
Butt it didn’t work out like that. Why? Because new battles had to be fought and the one with austerity was going be the most important of all for all our sakes. Read More The North still backs Brexit one year after EU referendum - but we're pessimistic 
For some it has become a life or death struggle due to the rigid confines of the austerity strait jacket at the ‘black’ heart of which is welfare cuts and public spending budgets slashed to the bone. 
Britain is now a brutally divided country at present, graphically illustrated by the Grenfell Tower tragedy in London. 
Corbyn and Labour chose to highlight this divide, their remedy being to tear down the wall surrounding the so-called ‘magic money tree’ - ie the nation’s earnings from our tax - and distribute it much more fairly. To prioritise the money to those who need it most whilst providing vital extra funds for the NHS and public services. 
All this thanks, I believe, to the Brexit vote and the domino effect it started. Like us on Facebook
